page.title: 17ROUDSEA WOOD-HOLKER MOSS
page.content: Roudsea Wood and Mosses National{ {Nature Reserve}was first established in 1955.It now covers 276 hecatres.It consists of an exceptionally diverse{ {woodland}which merges in the east with an estuarine{raised mire}complex known as the{mosses.}(Norse meaning peatbog) The woodland covers two ridges of contrasting geology separated by a shallow valley which contains a mire and a small tarn.The east ridge is{ {Carboniferous Limestone}and the west ridge is of{Bannisdale Slate.}These result in contrasting alkaline and acid soils and hence,different types of vegetation.The mire was once salt-marsh when sea levels were lower. The great variety of vegetation and wildlife has caused the wood to be designated a Grade 1 site of Special Scientific Interest by the{Nature {Conservancy Council}who manage it.
